snippet: The city’s top leader and his aides are said to hope that the disruption of the demonstrations will eventually turn the public against the pro-democracy protests. .
abstract: Hong Kong's chief executive Leung Chun-ying and his advisers have decided, with support from China’s leaders, that their best strategy is to wait and hope that disruption of everyday life will turn local public opinion against pro-democracy demonstrators; do not plan to use force to disperse demonstrations, but also will not negotiate with protest leaders.

byline.contributor: Reporting was contributed by Didi Kirsten Tatlow from Beijing, Chris Buckley, Alan Wong and Edward Wong from Hong Kong, and Julie Hirschfeld Davis from Washington.

lead_paragraph: The city’s top leader and his aides are said to hope that the disruption of the demonstrations will eventually turn the public against the pro-democracy protests. .

headline.main: Hong Kong Government’s Strategy on Protesters: Wait Them Out
headline.print_headline: Hong Kong Government’s Strategy on Protesters: Wait Them Out
